report_src: 玛格丽特·克莱尔·胡佛（Margaret Claire Hoover）出生于1977年12月11日[1]，按2024年7月的当前时间计算，她已46岁，将在同年12月11日迎来47岁。

question_en: When was Bangkok founded?
pos_context_en: Bangkok Noi was established as an amphoe on 15 October 1915. Originally named Amphoe Ammarin, it was renamed on 11 July 1916 to Amphoe Bangkok Noi to match with the historical name of the area. It became a khet in 1972 when Thon Buri and Bangkok were merged. Later on 9 November 1989 the Bang Phlat district was created from four of Bangkok Noi's sub-districts, leaving Bangkok Noi with four remaining sub-districts: Siri Rat, Ban Chang Lo, Bang Khun Non, and Bang Khun Si. On 12 December 1991 a small part of Bang Phlat district was moved back to Bangkok Noi, creating the new Arun Ammarin sub-district.
neg_context_title_en: Postage stamps and postal history of Bangkok
neg_context_en: Bangkok F.C. was founded in 1999. Its first name was Bangkok Bravo F.C., and then it was renamed to Bangkok F.C., in 2010 when Natthaphol Teepsuwan became the owner and the chairman of the club. He also changed the logo to be a bull on a background of the Giant Swing, which is a symbol of Bangkok. At that time Bangkok F.C. used Chaloem Phrakiat Bang Mod Stadium as their home field.

The Indian National Council was founded in December 1941 in Bangkok by another group of Indian nationalists resident in Thailand. This organisation was founded from the Thai-Bharat Cultural Lodge on 22 December 1941. The founding president of the Council was Swami Satyananda Puri, along with Debnath Das as the founding secretary. Along with the Indian Independence League, it came to be one of the two prominent Indian associations that corresponded with I Fujiwara's F Kikan on the scopes of Japanese assistance to the Indian movement. However, the Indian National Council emphasised solidarity with the Indian National Congress and, at a time when Japan began its successful Malayan Campaign, the council reflected the Congress leadership's reluctance to appear Quisling of the Japanese. The council also had differences with the Indian Independence League, with Puri openly questioning Tokyo's anti-imperialist credibility in light of her actions in Korea and China. Puri was killed in a plane crash, along with Giani Pritam Singh en route to the Conference in Tokyo in 1942 that saw Rash Behari Bose accepted as the leader of the expatriate Indian movement in South-east Asia. Later, the council sent delegates to attend the Bangkok Conference.

The history of Bangkok dates at least back to the early 15th century, when it was a village on the west bank of the Chao Phraya River, under the rule of Ayutthaya. Because of its strategic location near the mouth of the river, the town gradually increased in importance. Bangkok initially served as a customs outpost with forts on both sides of the river, and was the site of a siege in 1688 in which the French were expelled from Siam. After the fall of Ayutthaya to the Burmese Empire in 1767, the newly crowned King Taksin established his capital at the town, which became the base of the Thonburi Kingdom. In 1782, King Phutthayotfa Chulalok (Rama I) succeeded Taksin, moved the capital to the eastern bank's Rattanakosin Island, thus founding the Rattanakosin Kingdom. The City Pillar was erected on 21 April 1782, which is regarded as the date of foundation of the present city.

Over the past few decades the general trend of pursuing a university degree has prompted the founding of new universities to meet the needs of Thai students. Bangkok became not only a place where immigrants and provincial Thais go for job opportunities, but also for a chance to receive a university degree. Ramkhamhaeng University emerged in 1971 as Thailand's first open university; it now has the highest enrolment in the country. The demand for higher education has led to the founding of many other universities and colleges, both public and private. While many universities have been established in major provinces, the Greater Bangkok region remains home to the greater majority of institutions, and the city's tertiary education scene remains over-populated with non-Bangkokians. The situation is not limited to higher education, either. In the 1960s, 60 to 70 percent of 10- to 19-year-olds who were in school had migrated to Bangkok for secondary education. This was due to both a lack of secondary schools in the provinces and perceived higher standards of education in the capital. Although this discrepancy has since largely abated, tens of thousands of students still compete for places in Bangkok's leading schools. Education has long been a prime factor in the centralization of Bangkok and will play a vital role in the government's efforts to decentralize the country.

Bangkok's Chinatown is one of the largest Chinatowns in the world. It was founded in 1782 when the city was established as the capital of the Rattanakosin Kingdom, and served as the home of the mainly Teochew immigrant Chinese population, who soon became the city's dominant ethnic group. Originally centred around Sampheng, the core of Chinatown now lies along Yaowarat Road, which serves as its main artery and sometimes lends its name to the entire area, which is often referred to as Yaowarat (). Chinatown's entire area is roughly coterminous with Samphanthawong District, and includes neighbourhoods such as Song Wat and Talat Noi along the Chao Phraya River, and Charoen Chai, Khlong Thom and Nakhon Khasem along Charoen Krung Road.

By 1900, rural market zones in Bangkok began developing into residential districts. The Memorial Bridge was constructed in 1932 to connect Thonburi to Bangkok which was believed to promote economic growth and modernization in a period when infrastructure was developing considerably. Bangkok became the centre stage for power struggles between the military and political elite as the country abolished absolute monarchy in 1932. It was subject to Japanese occupation and Allied bombing during World War II. With the war over in 1945 British and Indian troops landed in September, and during their brief occupation of the city disarmed the Japanese troops. A significant event following the return of the young king Ananda Mahidol, intended to defuse post-war tensions lingering between Bangkok's ethnic Chinese and Thai people, was his visit to Bangkok's Chinatown Sam Peng Lane ().

A majority of Bangkok's population is of Thai ethnicity, although details on the city's ethnic make-up are unavailable, as the national census does not document race. Bangkok's cultural pluralism dates back to the early days of its founding: several ethnic communities were formed by immigrants and forced settlers included the Khmer, northern Thai, Lao, Vietnamese, Tavoyan, Mon and Malay. Most prominent were the Chinese, who played major roles in the city's trade and became the majority of Bangkok's population—estimates include up to three-fourths in 1828 and almost half in the 1950s. Chinese immigration was restricted from the 1930s and effectively ceased after the Chinese Revolution in 1949. Their prominence subsequently declined as younger generations of Thai Chinese integrated and adopted a Thai identity. Bangkok is still nevertheless home to a large Chinese community, with the greatest concentration in Yaowarat, Bangkok's Chinatown.

Initially, postage stamps of India were used here and throughout the Straits Settlements. This lasted until 1867 when Straits Settlements stamps were first produced. When Honorary Postmaster Gardner complained in 1881 that he should be compensated for the increasing amount of work that was required of him it was agreed that a portion of the revenue for stamp sales would be retained. This led to the overprinting during 1882 of Straits Settlement with the letter B, representing Bangkok, for use there. The Bangkok 30mm diameter circular date stamp postmark was also introduced during this period. Most outbound mail was still sent to enter the postal system at Singapore (for European destinations). Some Hong Kong stamps continued to be used throughout this time for mail forwarded through Hong Kong to Chinese, Japanese, and United States destinations. A few British stamps are also known to have been used in Bangkok. Inbound mail from steamboats was kept at the post office for people to come to pick up.

The Bangkok Dock Company (1957) Limited () is a Thai shipbuilding company. It operates as a state enterprise under the oversight of the Ministry of Defence. It was founded in 1865 as the Bangkok Dock Co by Captain John Bush, the harbour master of Bangkok, and was acquired by the Royal Thai Navy in 1957. The company now has two facilities: the original Bangkok dockyard on Charoen Krung Road next to Wat Yan Nawa, and a newer main facility operating at the Mahidol Adulyadej Naval Dockyard at Sattahip in Chonburi Province.
question_src: 曼谷什么时候成立？
pos_context_src: 曼谷诺伊（Noi）于1915年10月15日被建立为两把。 1972年，当Thon Buri和Mangkok合并时，它成为了Khet。 1989年11月9日晚些时候，Bang Phlat区是由曼谷Noi的四个街区创建的，使曼谷Noi剩下四个分区：Siri Rat，Ban Chang Lo，Bang Khun Non和Bang Khun Si。 1991年12月12日，Bang Phlat区的一小部分被转回曼谷Noi，创建了新的Arun Ammarin街区。
neg_context_title_src: 邮票和曼谷的邮政历史
neg_context_src: 曼谷F.C.成立于1999年。其名字是曼谷Bravo F.C.，然后在2010年Natthaphol Teepsuwan成为俱乐部的所有者和董事长。他还将徽标更改为巨型挥杆背景的公牛，这是曼谷的象征。当时曼谷F.C.使用Chaloem Phrakiat Bang mod体育场作为本地场。

印度国民议会于1941年12月由泰国的另一批印度民族主义者在曼谷成立。该组织于1941年12月22日是从泰国巴拉特文化小屋成立的。安理会的创始主席是斯瓦米·萨蒂亚南达·普里（Swami Satyananda Puri），以及德巴纳特·达斯（Debnath Das）担任创始秘书。与印度独立联盟一起，这是与I富士的F Kikan相对应的两个杰出的印度协会之一，而日本对印度运动的援助范围。但是，印度国民议会强调了对印度国民大会的团结，在日本开始成功的马来亚竞选活动的时候，理事会反映了国会领导人不愿意出现日本人。理事会也与印度独立联盟有所不同，根据她在韩国和中国的行动，普里公开质疑东京的反帝国主义信誉。普里（Puri）在一次飞机失事中被杀，1942年，吉安尼·普里塔姆·辛格（Giani Pritam Singh）前往东京会议，拉什·贝哈里·贝斯（Rash Behari Bose）被接受为东南亚印度外籍人士运动的领导人。后来，理事会派代表参加曼谷会议。

曼谷的历史至少可以追溯到15世纪初期，当时它是乔特塔亚（Ayutthaya）统治下的乔·菲拉亚河（Chao Phraya River）西岸的一个村庄。由于其在河口附近的战略位置，该镇的重要性逐渐增加。曼谷最初是海关前哨基地，在河的两边都有要塞，是1688年的攻城场，法国人被从暹罗开除。 1767年，阿育特亚（Ayutthaya）倒台到缅甸帝国之后，新冠冕的塔克辛国王在镇上建立了他的首都，该镇成为了汤堡王国的基地。 1782年，国王Phutthayotfa Chulalok（Rama I）接任Taksin，将首都搬到了东岸的Rattanakosin岛，从而建立了Rattanakosin王国。该城市支柱于1782年4月21日竖立，被视为当前城市的基础。

在过去的几十年中，攻读大学学位的一般趋势促使新大学建立了泰国学生的需求。曼谷不仅成为移民和省泰国人寻求工作机会的地方，而且也有机会获得大学学位。 Ramkhamhaeng University于1971年成为泰国的第一所开放大学。现在，它的入学人数最高。对高等教育的需求导致了许多其他大学和大学的建立。尽管许多大学是在大省建立的，但曼谷更大的地区仍然是大多数机构的所在地，该市的高等教育现场仍然被非邦库克人所容纳。情况也不仅限于高等教育。在1960年代，在学校上学的10至19岁年轻人中有60％迁移到曼谷接受中学教育。这是由于各省缺乏中学和首都教育水平的较高。尽管此后这种差异已大大减轻，但成千上万的学生仍在争夺曼谷领先学校的地方。长期以来，教育一直是曼谷集中化的主要因素，并将在政府分散该国的努力中发挥至关重要的作用。

曼谷的唐人街是世界上最大的唐人街之一。它成立于1782年，当时该市被建立为藤植物王国的首都，并成为主要是蒂奥切移民中国人口的家，后者很快成为该市的主要种族。最初以Sampheng为中心，Sampheng的核心现在位于Yaowarat Road沿线，该路是其主要动脉，有时将其名称贴在整个地区，通常称为Yaowarat（）。唐人街的整个地区与Samphanthawong区大致相当，包括Chao Phraya河沿岸的Song Wat和Talat Noi等社区，以及Charoen Krung Road沿岸的Charoen Chai，Khlong Thom和Nakhon Khasem。

到1900年，曼谷的农村市场开始发展到住宅区。纪念桥建于1932年，目的是将Thonburi与曼谷联系起来，据信，在基础设施大大发展的时期，据信促进经济增长和现代化。随着该国于1932年废除了绝对君主制，曼谷成为军事与政治精英之间权力斗争的中心舞台。这在第二次世界大战期间受到日本占领和盟军的轰炸。随着1945年的战争，英国和印度军队于9月份降落，在短暂占领城市期间，日军解除武装。年轻的国王阿南达·马希多（Ananda Mahidol）返回后，旨在消化曼谷中国人和泰国人民之间的战后紧张局势，这是一项重大事件，是他访问了曼谷的唐人街唐人街萨姆·彭·莱恩（Sam Sam Peng Lane）（）。

曼谷的大多数人口都是泰国种族，尽管有关该市种族化妆的细节不可用，因为国家人口普查没有记录种族。曼谷的文化多元化可以追溯到其成立的早期：几个民族社区是由移民和强迫定居者组成的，其中包括高棉，泰国北部，老挝，越南人，越南，塔沃扬，蒙和马来人。最著名的是中国人，他在该市的贸易中扮演着重要角色，并成为曼谷人口的大多数 - 估计包括1828年最多三分之三，而在1950年代将几乎一半。中国的移民受到1930年代的限制，并在1949年中国革命后有效停止。随后，随着年轻一代的泰国人融合并采用了泰语身份，他们的突出声音下降了。尽管如此，曼谷仍然是一个大型中国社区的所在地，在曼谷的唐人街Yaowarat的集中度最高。

最初，这里以及整个海峡定居点都使用了印度的邮票。一直持续到1867年，当时海峡定居点邮票首次制作。当荣誉邮政局长加德纳（Gardner）在1881年抱怨说，他应该为他所要求的越来越多的工作得到补偿，因此同意将保留一部分邮票销售收入。这导致在1882年与代表曼谷的字母B的海峡定居点的层面上泛滥，以便在那里使用。在此期间，还引入了曼谷直径30毫米圆形邮票邮票。大多数出站邮件仍被发送到新加坡（欧洲目的地）进入邮政系统。在这段时间里，一些香港邮票继续被用于通过香港转发给中国，日本和美国目的地的邮件。众所周知，一些英国邮票已在曼谷使用。邮政局的入站邮件被保留在邮局，供人们接送。

曼谷码头公司（1957）有限公司（）是一家泰国造船公司。它在国防部监督下以国家企业的身份运营。它由曼谷港口大师约翰·布什（John Bush）上尉成立于1865年，是曼谷港口大师，并于1957年被皇家泰国海军收购。该公司现在有两个设施：Charoen Krung Road旁边的原始设施，位于Wat Yan Nawa旁边的Charoen Krung Road上，并在Wat Yan Nawa和一个较新的Mahidol aduly dopyare docky atheard artheard artheard artheard artheard artheard artheard sattheard sattheard sattheard sattheard sattheard sattheard sattheard satt。
report_src: 根据现有资料，曼谷诺伊区（Bangkok Noi）作为行政区划最早可追溯到1915年10月15日，当天其被设立为一个“两把”（县级行政单位）[1]。

question_en: When was New Zealand first settled?
pos_context_en: The precise date at which the first inhabitants of New Zealand reached Otago and the extreme south (known to later Māori as "Murihiku") remains uncertain. Māori descend from a race of Polynesian sea-wanderers who, moved from East Asia and south-east Asia to the islands of the Pacific. Tradition tells of their further journeyings from Hawaiki to New Zealand, and some commentators have identified this homeland as Havai'i, an island in the Society Group. Overpopulation, scarcity of food and civil war forced many of them to migrate once more, and New Zealand became their new home. Māori settled New Zealand between AD 1280–1320. They quickly learnt to hunt the numerous species of moa and seals in New Zealand and settled across the North and South islands in less than a few decades. There is a change in the pollen record from inland Otago from 600 years ago from a forest to bracken flora. It has been inferred that this relates to fires being lit during Maori exploration.
neg_context_en: The history of New Zealand dates back at least 700 years to when it was discovered and settled by Polynesians, who developed a distinct Māori culture centred on kinship links and land. The first European explorer to sight New Zealand was Dutch navigator Abel Tasman on 13 December 1642. The Dutch were also the first non-natives to explore and chart New Zealand's coastline. Captain James Cook, who reached New Zealand in October 1769 on the first of his three voyages, was the first European explorer to circumnavigate and map New Zealand. From the late 18th century, the country was regularly visited by explorers and other sailors, missionaries, traders and adventurers. In 1840 the Treaty of Waitangi was signed between the British Crown and various Māori chiefs, bringing New Zealand into the British Empire and giving Māori the same rights as British subjects. There was extensive British settlement throughout the rest of the century and into the early part of the next century. War and the imposition of a European economic and legal system led to most of New Zealand's land passing from Māori to Pākehā (European) ownership, and most Māori subsequently became impoverished.

The military history of New Zealand is an aspect of the history of New Zealand that spans several hundred years. When first settled by Māori almost a millennium ago, there was much land and resources, but war began to break out as the country's carrying capacity was approached. Initially being fought with close range weapons of wood and stone, this continued on and off until Europeans arrived, bringing with them new weapons such as muskets. Colonisation by Britain led to the New Zealand land wars in the 19th century in which settler and imperial troops and their Māori allies fought against other Māori and a handful of Pākehā. In the first half of the 20th century, New Zealanders of all races fought alongside Britain in the Boer War and both World Wars. In the second half of the century and into this century the New Zealand Defence Force has provided token assistance to the United States in several conflicts. New Zealand has also contributed troops extensively to multilateral peacekeeping operations.

The History of New Zealand dates back to at least 700 years to when it was discovered and settled by Polynesians, who developed a distinct Māori culture centred on kinship links and land. The first European explorer, the Dutch Abel Tasman, came to New Zealand in 1642. From the late 18th century, the country was regularly visited by explorers and other sailors, missionaries, traders and adventurers. In 1840 the Treaty of Waitangi was signed between the British Crown and various Māori chiefs, bringing New Zealand into the British Empire and giving Māori equal rights with British citizens. There was extensive European and some Asian settlement throughout the rest of the century. War and the imposition of a European economic and legal system led to most of New Zealand's land passing from Māori to European ownership, and most Māori subsequently became impoverished.

Polynesians in the South Pacific were the first to discover the landmass of New Zealand. Eastern Polynesian explorers had settled in New Zealand by approximately the thirteenth century CE with most evidence pointing to an arrival date of about 1280. Their arrival gave rise to the Māori culture and the Māori language, both unique to New Zealand, although very closely related to analogues in other parts of Eastern Polynesia. Evidence from Wairau Bar and the Chatham Islands shows that the Polynesian colonists maintained many parts of their east Polynesian culture such as burial customs for at least 50 years. Especially strong resemblances link Māori to the languages and cultures of the Cook and Society Islands, which are regarded as the most likely places of origin. Moriori settled the Chatham Islands during the 15th century from SE South Island of New Zealand.

Several Baptists settled in New Zealand in the 1840s, but the first Baptist minister, Decimus Dolamore from Yorkshire, England, did not arrive until May 1851. Dolamore settled in Nelson and was involved in the formation of the first Baptist Church in New Zealand - Nelson Baptist Church - that same year. He was instrumental in obtaining a change in the law to allow Baptist ministers to perform marriage ceremonies; until 1854, only Catholic and Anglican priests were allowed to do so. Dolamore later went to Christchurch and was the first minister for that congregation.

After receiving a compilation on forming Assemblies they then returned to New Zealand in December 1925. They also returned with some dust from the Tomb of Bahá'u'lláh which was placed in New Zealand soil at Stevenson's home in a ceremony held on 14 February 1926. Later in 1926 the Bahá'ís in Auckland were able to properly elect their first Bahá'í Local Spiritual Assembly. In 1928 there were seven assemblies between New Zealand and Australia - by 1939 the number of assemblies had reduced to 4 but the locations with Bahá'ís increased to 17 and by 1940 the count of assemblies reached 19 while there were still 17 other locations with smaller groups of Bahá'ís. In 1931 Keith Ransom-Kehler also visited. In 1934 Bahá'ís from Australia and New Zealand elected a regional National Assembly - there were three delegates from Auckland, three from Sydney and three from Adelaide. From 1934 to 1939 Stevenson served on the regional National Spiritual Assembly of Australia and New Zealand and then died shortly thereafter in 1941. In 1940 the community held its first season school. In 1947 Alvin and Gertrude Blum left the United States for New Zealand where they lived until 1953 when they pioneered and became Knights of Bahá'u'lláh for the Solomon Islands.
In 1948 the first person of Māori descent to accept the Bahá’í Faith was Albert White, who was one quarter Māori. In 1949 the first Persian Bahá'í pioneer, Manoochehr Ala’i, arrived as a student at Massey College. In 1953 the first standing Hand of the Cause, the highest appointed position in the religion open to all, `Alí-Akbar Furútan, visited New Zealand. In 1957 the New Zealand community held its first independent convention to elect its own National Spiritual Assembly with three delegates from Auckland and two each from Devonport, New Plymouth and Wellington. This convention elected the first National Spiritual Assembly of New Zealand. In 1958 Hand of the Cause of God, Enoch Olinga visited the Ngaruawahia Marae and talked with elders and four years later, when Hand of the Cause of God, Dr Muhajir visited, Ephraim Te Paa, a Kaumatua (Māori elder) from Ahipara converted to the religion. In 1963 with the election of the Universal House of Justice the Hands of the Cause updated and published a kind of census of the religion. At that time there were four assemblies -Auckland, Devonport, Hamilton, Wellington - and 18 localities with smaller groups of Bahá'ís - see maps. The story of one convert in 1964 includes her concern for her bi-racial children and despair at the bigotry of interracial marriage among the very minorities her children were members (she being Celt and married a Māori) when she found this kind of marriage highly accepted among Bahá'ís. The members of the National Assembly, who participated in the convention for the first election of the Universal House of Justice, were: Hugh Blundell, John Carr, Margaret Harnish, Linda Hight, Percy Leadley, Phyllis Milne, Jean Simmons, Douglas Weeks, and Terry Stirling. The New Zealand Bahá'í community came to the assistance of refugees in 1979 from the persecution of Bahá'ís in Iran who were allowed to settle in New Zealand. Between 1987 and 1989, a further 142 Iranian Bahá'ís settled in New Zealand.

From the 1790s, New Zealand was visited by British, French and American whaling, sealing and trading ships. Their crews traded European goods with the indigenous Māori. The first settlers to New Zealand were mainly from Australia, many of them ex-convicts or escaped convicts. Sailors, explorers and traders from Australia and other parts of Europe also settled.

New Zealand's religious history after the arrival of Europeans saw substantial missionary activity, with Māori generally converting to Christianity voluntarily (compare forced conversions elsewhere in the world). The Anglican Church Missionary Society (CMS) sent missionaries to settle in New Zealand. Samuel Marsden of the Church Missionary Society (chaplain in New South Wales) officiated at its first service on Christmas Day in 1814, at Oihi Bay in the Bay of Islands. The CMS founded its first mission at Rangihoua in the Bay of Islands in 1814 and over the next decade established farms and schools in the area. In June 1823 Wesleydale, the first Wesleyan Methodist mission in New Zealand, was established at Kaeo, near Whangaroa Harbour. Jean Baptiste Pompallier arrived in 1838 and became the first Catholic bishop in New Zealand. With a number of Marist Brothers, Pompallier organised the Catholic Church throughout the country. In 1892 the New Zealand Church Missionary Society (NZCMS) formed in a Nelson church hall and the first New Zealand missionaries were sent overseas soon after.

Sometime between 1250 and 1300, Polynesians settled in the islands that later were named New Zealand and developed a distinctive Māori culture. In 1642, Dutch explorer Abel Tasman became the first European to sight New Zealand. In 1840, representatives of the United Kingdom and Māori chiefs signed the Treaty of Waitangi, which declared British sovereignty over the islands. In 1841, New Zealand became a colony within the British Empire and in 1907 it became a dominion; it gained full statutory independence in 1947 and the British monarch remained the head of state. Today, the majority of New Zealand's population of 4.9 million is of European descent; the indigenous Māori are the largest minority, followed by Asians and Pacific Islanders. Reflecting this, New Zealand's culture is mainly derived from Māori and early British settlers, with recent broadening arising from increased immigration. The official languages are English, Māori, and NZ Sign Language, with English being very dominant.
question_src: 新西兰什么时候首次定居？
pos_context_src: 新西兰第一批居民到达奥塔哥的确切日期和最南端（后来毛利人称为“ Murihiku”）仍然不确定。毛利人来自波利尼西亚海浪者的种族，他们从东亚和东南亚搬到了太平洋岛屿。传统讲述了他们从哈瓦基（Hawaiki）到新西兰的进一步旅行，一些评论员将这个家园确定为社会群体中的一个岛屿Havai'i。人口过多，食物和内战的稀缺迫使他们中的许多人再次迁移，新西兰成为他们的新家。毛利人在AD 1280–1320之间定居新西兰。他们很快学会了在不到几十年的时间里狩猎新西兰的众多MOA和海豹，并定居在北部和南岛。从600年前，奥塔哥的花粉记录发生了变化，从森林到布拉肯植物群。据推断，这与毛利人探索期间的火灾有关。
neg_context_title_src: 巴哈伊对新西兰的信仰
neg_context_src: 新西兰的历史至少可以追溯到700年来，到了波利尼西亚人发现和定居时，他开发了一种以亲属关系和土地为中心的毛利人文化。 1642年12月13日，新西兰的第一位欧洲探险家是荷兰航海家亚伯·塔斯曼（Abel Tasman）。荷兰人也是第一个探索和绘制新西兰海岸线的非本地人。詹姆斯·库克（James Cook）上尉于1769年10月在他的三场航行中的第一次到达新西兰，他是第一个绕行和绘制新西兰的欧洲探险家。从18世纪后期开始，该国经常被探险家和其他水手，传教士，商人和冒险家拜访。 1840年，《威塔吉条约》（Waitangi）在英国王冠和各种毛利人酋长之间签署，将新西兰带入大英帝国，并赋予毛利人与英国臣民相同的权利。在整个世纪的剩余时间里，都有广泛的英国定居点，到了下一个世纪初。战争和实施欧洲经济和法律制度导致新西兰的大部分土地从毛利人传给帕凯哈（欧洲）所有权，随后大多数毛利人随后变得贫穷。

新西兰的军事历史是跨越数百年的新西兰历史的一个方面。大约一千年前首次由毛利人定居时，有很多土地和资源，但是随着该国的载荷能力接近，战争开始爆发。最初是用近距离的木材和石头武器作战的，这一直持续到欧洲人到达，并带来新武器，例如步枪。英国的殖民化导致了19世​​纪的新西兰土地战争，在19世纪，定居者和帝国军队及其毛利盟友与其他毛利人和少数帕基哈战斗。在20世纪上半叶，在布尔战争和两次世界大战中，所有种族的新西兰人都与英国并肩作战。在本世纪下半年和本世纪，新西兰国防军在几次冲突中向美国提供了象征性的援助。新西兰还为多边维持和平行动做出了广泛的贡献。

新西兰的历史可以追溯到至少700年，到达了波利尼西亚人发现和定居的时候，他开发了一种独特的毛利文化，以亲属关系和土地为中心。第一位欧洲探险家荷兰亚伯·塔斯曼（Abel Tasman）于1642年来到新西兰。从18世纪后期开始，该国经常被探险家和其他水手，传教士，商人和冒险家拜访。 1840年，《怀温条约》（Waitangi）的条约在英国王室和各种毛利人酋长之间签署，将新西兰带入大英帝国，并赋予毛利人与英国公民平等权利。在整个世纪剩余的时间里，欧洲有广泛的和亚洲的定居点。战争和强加欧洲经济和法律制度导致新西兰大部分从毛利人传给欧洲所有权，随后大多数毛利人都变得贫穷。

南太平洋的波利尼西亚人是第一个发现新西兰大陆的人。东波利尼西亚探险家在公元13世纪大约在新西兰定居，大多数证据表明到达日期约为1280年。他们的到来引起了毛利语文化和毛利语的语言，这些语言是新西兰独有的，尽管与东部波利尼西亚其他地区的类似物非常密切。 Wairau Bar和Chatham群岛的证据表明，波利尼西亚殖民者在东波利尼西亚文化的许多地方（例如埋葬习俗）至少维持了至少50年。特别是强烈的相似之处，将毛利人与厨师和社会岛的语言和文化联系起来，这些语言和文化被认为是最有可能的原产地。 15世纪，莫里奥里（Moriori）从新西兰南部的南岛定居了查塔姆群岛。
1840年代，几名浸信会定居在新西兰，但第一任浸信会部长，来自英格兰约克郡的Decimus Dolamore直到1851年5月才到达。Dolamore定居在尼尔森，并参与了新西兰第一届浸信会教堂 - 尼尔森浸信会教堂。他有助于获得法律的改变，以允许浸信会长进行结婚仪式。直到1854年，只有天主教和英国国教祭司才被允许这样做。多拉莫尔后来去了基督城，是该会众的第一任部长。

在收到组建集会的汇编后，他们随后于1925年12月返回新西兰。他们还从巴哈乌拉墓中的一些灰尘返回，该墓地于1926年2月14日在史蒂文森的新西兰土地上放置在史蒂文森家的新西兰土地上。1926年2月14日，在1926年后期举行的Bahá'ís。 1928年，新西兰和澳大利亚之间有七个集会 - 到1939年，大会的数量减少到4个，但与巴哈伊人的地点增加到17个，到1940年，总会数量达到19个，而还有17个其他地方，而其他较小的巴哈伊人则有17个地点。 1931年，基思·兰索姆·凯勒（Keith Ransom-Kehler）也参观了。 1934年，来自澳大利亚和新西兰的巴哈伊人选举了一个地区国民议会 - 来自奥克兰的三名代表，三名来自悉尼，三名来自阿德莱德。从1934年到1939年，史蒂文森（Stevenson）在澳大利亚和新西兰地区国家精神大会任职，然后于1941年不久去世。 1947年，阿尔文（Alvin）和格特鲁德·布鲁姆（Gertrude Blum）离开美国前往新西兰，直到1953年他们开创性，并成为所罗门群岛的巴哈乌尔夫人。 1948年，毛利人血统的第一个接受巴哈伊信仰的人是四分之一毛利人的阿尔伯特·怀特（Albert White）。 1949年，第一个波斯语巴哈伊先驱者Manoochehr Ala’i以学生的身份到达Massey College。 1953年，这一事业的第一手是宗教开放的最高任命的立场。 1957年，新西兰社区举行了第一次独立大会，与来自奥克兰的三名代表一起选举自己的民族精神大会，每个代表来自德文波特，新普利茅斯和惠灵顿。该公约选举了新西兰的第一次民族精神大会。 1958年，上帝的事业之手，以伊诺瓦（Enoch Olinga）访问了Ngaruawahia Marae并与之交谈 长者和四年后，当神的事故之手穆哈吉尔博士拜访了埃弗莱姆·泰帕（Ephraim te Paa），这是一位来自ahipara的Kaumatua（毛利人）转变为宗教。 1963年，随着普世司法众议院的选举，该事业的手的更新并发表了一种宗教的普查。当时有四个议会 - 亚克兰，德文波特，汉密尔顿，惠灵顿 - 以及18个地区的巴哈伊人群 - 参见地图。 1964年，一个convert依者的故事包括她对两种种族子女的关注，以及在她的孩子中的少数群体中的异族婚姻偏执的偏执之中，当她发现这种婚姻在巴哈伊人中高度接受时。国民议会的成员参加了《世界司法众议院》第一次选举的大会，是：休·布伦德尔，约翰·卡尔，玛格丽特·哈尼什，琳达·希特，珀西·莱德利，珀西·莱德利，菲利斯·米尔恩，让·西蒙斯，道格拉斯·韦克斯和特里·斯特里。新西兰巴哈伊社区于1979年遭到迫害在伊朗的巴哈伊人的协助，他们被允许在新西兰定居。在1987年至1989年之间，另外142个伊朗巴哈伊人定居在新西兰。
从1790年代开始，新西兰被英国，法国和美国捕鲸，密封和贸易船访问。他们的船员用毛利土著人交易了欧洲商品。第一批到新西兰的定居者主要来自澳大利亚，其中许多是前罪犯或逃脱的罪犯。来自澳大利亚和欧洲其他地区的水手，探险家和商人也定居。

欧洲人到来后，新西兰的宗教历史进行了实质性的传教活动，毛利人通常自愿转变为基督教（比较世界其他地方的强迫conversion依）。英国国教教堂宣教协会（CMS）派遣传教士定居在新西兰。教堂宣教协会的塞缪尔·马斯登（Samuel Marsden）（新南威尔士州的牧师）于1814年圣诞节那天在岛屿湾的oihi湾举行了仪式。 CMS于1814年在岛屿湾的Rangihoua建立了第一个任务，并在未来十年内建立了该地区的农场和学校。 1823年6月，卫斯理代尔（Wesleydale）是新西兰的第一个卫斯理卫理公会任务，在旺加罗阿港口附近的凯奥（Kaeo）成立。让·巴蒂斯特·庞普利埃（Jean Baptiste Pompallier）于1838年抵达，成为新西兰的第一任天主教主教。庞帕利尔（Pompallier）与许多马里斯特兄弟（Marist Brothers）一起组织了全国的天主教会。 1892年，新西兰教会宣教协会（NZCMS）在尼尔森教堂大厅和新西兰第一批传教士中成立，不久之后就被派往海外。

在1250年至1300年之间的某个时候，波利尼西亚人定居在后来被命名为新西兰的岛屿，并发展了一种独特的毛利文化。 1642年，荷兰探险家亚伯·塔斯曼（Abel Tasman）成为第一个看到新西兰的欧洲人。 1840年，英国和毛利人酋长的代表签署了《怀温条约》，该条约宣布为英国对岛屿的主权。 1841年，新西兰成为大英帝国的殖民地，并于1907年成为统治。它在1947年获得了完全的法定独立性，而英国君主仍然是国家元首。如今，新西兰的490万人口中的大多数是欧洲下降。土著毛利人是最大的少数民族，其次是亚洲人和太平洋岛民。反映这一点，新西兰的文化主要源自毛利人和早期的英国定居者，最近由于移民的增加而扩大。官方语言是英语，毛利语和新西兰手语，英语非常占主导地位。
report_src: 根据现有考古与口述历史证据，最早抵达并定居新西兰的是来自波利尼西亚的毛利人，他们约在公元1280年至1320年之间登陆并开始长期居住，因此新西兰的首次人类定居时间可确定在这一时期 [1]。

question_en: What years did Glenn "Pop" Warner live?
pos_context_en: Glenn Scobey Warner (April 5, 1871 – September 7, 1954), most commonly known as Pop Warner, was an American college football coach at various institutions who is responsible for several key aspects of the modern game. Included among his innovations are the single and double wing formations (precursors of the modern spread and shotgun formations), the three point stance and the body blocking technique. Fellow pioneer coach Amos Alonzo Stagg called Warner "one of the excellent creators". He was inducted as a coach into the College Football Hall of Fame as part of its inaugural class in 1951. He also contributed to a junior football program which became known as Pop Warner Little Scholars, a popular youth American football organization.
neg_context_title_en: 1940 San Jose State Spartans football team
neg_context_en: Warner was the brother of famed football coach Pop Warner. In 1902, Bill and Glenn both played pro football for the Syracuse Athletic Club during the first World Series of Football, held at Madison Square Garden. It was during this event, that Warner played in the very first professional indoor football game as his Syracuse squad upset the heavily favored "New York" team. While Glenn was injured during the event with a head injury, Bill and the rest of the Syracuse team went on to win the event.

Glenn "Pop" Warner coached at several schools throughout his career, including the University of Georgia, Cornell University, University of Pittsburgh, Stanford University, and Temple University. One of his most famous stints was at the Carlisle Indian Industrial School, where he coached Jim Thorpe, who went on to become the first president of the National Football League, an Olympic Gold Medalist, and is widely considered one of the best overall athletes in history. Warner wrote one of the first important books of football strategy, "Football for Coaches and Players", published in 1927. Though the shift was invented by Stagg, Warner's single wing and double wing formations greatly improved upon it; for almost 40 years, these were among the most important formations in football. As part of his single and double wing formations, Warner was one of the first coaches to effectively utilize the forward pass. Among his other innovations are modern blocking schemes, shoulder pads, and the three-point stance. The youth football league, Pop Warner Little Scholars, was named in his honor.

Glenn "Pop" Warner coached at several schools throughout his career, including the University of Georgia, Cornell University, University of Pittsburgh, Stanford University, Iowa State University, and Temple University. One of his most famous stints was at the Carlisle Indian Industrial School, where he coached Jim Thorpe, who went on to become the first president of the National Football League, an Olympic Gold Medalist, and is widely considered one of the best overall athletes in history. Warner wrote one of the first important books of football strategy, "Football for Coaches and Players", published in 1927. Though the shift was invented by Stagg, Warner's single wing and double wing formations greatly improved upon it; for almost 40 years, these were among the most important formations in football. As part of his single and double wing formations, Warner was one of the first coaches to effectively utilize the forward pass. Among his other innovations are modern blocking schemes, the three-point stance, and the reverse play. The youth football league, Pop Warner Little Scholars, was named in his honor.

Wilton lettered three seasons (1926–1928) in football for Glenn Scobey "Pop" Warner at Stanford University. In his three years the Stanford football team went a combined 26–5–3 with two trips to the Rose Bowl. In 1927 against USC he caught a 74-yard touchdown pass from Biff Hoffman, which was at the time the longest in Stanford history.

While coaching at Temple, Warner continued living in Palo Alto (where Stanford is located). After his 1938 retirement he was immediately recruited as an advisor to Dudley DeGroot, a center at Stanford and head coach at San Jose State University (near Palo Alto). Officially an advisor, Warner was immediately put in charge of the offense. According to Powers, "DeGroot had been using a single back offense but Pop immediately changed to the double wing, much to the doubts of San Jose players. However, the formation began to click and San Jose not only enjoyed an undefeated season but was the highest scoring team in the nation." That year the San Jose State Spartans played against College of the Pacific, coached by Amos Alonzo Stagg. It was the first time the two coaches had met since 1907, when Warner was coaching Carlisle and defeated Stagg's University of Chicago 18–4. Warner and DeGroot's San Jose State defeated Stagg's Pacific Tigers, 39–0.

During the first 40 years of organized varsity college lacrosse, known alternately as the ICLA, ILA, USICLL, USILL and USILA, two Pennsylvania schools, Lehigh and Swarthmore fielded dominant teams. The two teams were voted National Champions of college lacrosse a combined fourteen (14) seasons. Glenn "Pop" Warner, the Hall of Fame football coach at the Carlisle Indian School (PA) from 1899 to 1903, substituted lacrosse for baseball during the spring season because he said, "Lacrosse is a developer of health and strength. It is a game that spectators rave over once they understand it." It is also likely that lacrosse, a contact sport, helped prepare his football players for the fall season. By 1920, the USILL had expanded to include teams from Syracuse, Rutgers, Penn State and, encouraged by Pop Warner, even considered adding a varsity team at the University of Pittsburgh. In 1920, college lacrosse realigned their association, adding a Southern Division, which included powerful teams from Lehigh, Penn and Swarthmore along with traditional Maryland power Johns Hopkins. The United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association (USILA), the organization still in existence today, officially was formed in November 1925.
Famed football coach Glenn Scobey "Pop" Warner was an advisory coach for the Spartans in 1939 and 1940, helping the team to a 24–1 record over the two seasons.

The following are the conference's various Player of the Year award recipients. In 2004 the Defensive Player of the Year award was renamed the Pat Tillman Defensive Player of the Year.
The Glenn "Pop" Warner Memorial Trophy was awarded annually by the Palo Club to the most valuable senior player on the West Coast. It was awarded from 1950 to 2004. Notably, all recipients played for Pac-10 institutions. The award is distinguished from the unaffiliated W. J. Voit Memorial Trophy, presented annually from 1951 to 1978 to the top player on the Pacific Coast regardless of class-year.

Although the 1915 season was a success, the next year's team was one of the greatest of Warner's career. The Panthers were again undefeated and, like the previous year, six of the eight games were shutouts. Thirty-two of their 35 players were from Western Pennsylvania, near Pittsburgh. The team scored 255 points, conceding 25. Warner considered the team an improvement because its defense was more dominant than the previous year's. The Panthers were the consensus national champions, and Warner became recognized as one of football's greatest coaches.
In 1917 the United States entered World War I, and some players (including Andy Hastings and Jimmy Dehart) entered military service. Pittsburgh played an undefeated full season despite the war, although it was not awarded the national championship. Although the team lacked the previous year's punch, it dominated the opposition. A key aspect of its success was the opposing coaches' inability to address Warner's evolving strategies; according to Powers, "His reverse plays were a mystery, although Pop always was willing to explain them in detail to any other coach".
question_src: 格伦（Glenn）“流行”华纳（Pop）生活几年？
pos_context_src: 格伦·斯科比·华纳（Glenn Scobey Warner）（1871年4月5日至1954年9月7日），最常被称为流行华纳（Pop Warner），是各个机构的美国大学橄榄球教练，负责现代游戏的几个关键方面。在他的创新中包括单翼和双翼地层（现代传播和shot弹枪的前体），三点立场和身体阻塞技术。先驱教练阿莫斯·阿隆佐·斯塔格（Amos Alonzo Stagg）称华纳（Warner）为“出色的创作者之一”。作为1951年就职班的一部分，他被入选了大学橄榄球名人堂的教练。他还为一项少年足球计划做出了贡献，该计划被称为流行的青年美式足球组织Pop Warner Little Scholars。
neg_context_title_src: 曲棍球在宾夕法尼亚州
1940年圣何塞州立斯巴达足球队
neg_context_src: 华纳是著名的足球教练流行华纳的兄弟。 1902年，比尔（Bill）和格伦（Glenn）在麦迪逊广场花园（Madison Square Garden）举行的第一场世界足球比赛中都为锡拉丘兹体育俱乐部踢出职业足球。正是在这次比赛中，华纳参加了第一场职业室内足球比赛，因为他的锡拉丘兹（Syracuse）小队不高兴这支受人青睐的“纽约”球队。在比赛期间因头部受伤而受伤时，比尔和锡拉丘兹的其他团队继续赢得比赛。

格伦“流行”华纳在整个职业生涯中都在几所学校执教，包括佐治亚大学，康奈尔大学，匹兹堡大学，斯坦福大学和坦普尔大学。他最著名的任职者之一是在卡莱尔印度工业学校（Carlisle Indian Industrial School），在那里他执教吉姆·索普（Jim Thorpe），后者继续成为奥运会金牌得主国家橄榄球联盟的第一任总统，并被广泛认为是历史上最好的整体运动员之一。华纳（Warner）写了第一本重要的足球战略书籍之一，“教练和球员的足球”，于1927年出版。在将近40年的时间里，这些是足球中最重要的地层之一。作为他的单翼和双翼队伍的一部分，华纳是最早有效利用前传球的教练之一。他的其他创新包括现代封锁方案，肩膀垫和三点立场。青年足球联盟流行华纳小学者以他的荣誉命名。

格伦“流行”华纳在整个职业生涯中都在几所学校执教，包括佐治亚大学，康奈尔大学，匹兹堡大学，斯坦福大学，爱荷华州立大学和坦普尔大学。他最著名的任职者之一是在卡莱尔印度工业学校（Carlisle Indian Industrial School），在那里他执教吉姆·索普（Jim Thorpe），后者继续成为奥运会金牌得主国家橄榄球联盟的第一任总统，并被广泛认为是历史上最好的整体运动员之一。华纳（Warner）写了第一本重要的足球战略书籍之一，“教练和球员的足球”，于1927年出版。在将近40年的时间里，这些是足球中最重要的地层之一。作为他的单翼和双翼队伍的一部分，华纳是最早有效利用前传球的教练之一。他的其他创新包括现代封锁计划，三分立场和反向戏剧。青年足球联盟流行华纳小学者以他的荣誉命名。

威尔顿（Wilton）在斯坦福大学（Stanford University）的格伦·斯科比（Glenn Scobey）“流行”华纳（Glenn Scobey）“流行”（Glenn Scobey）的足球比赛中写了三个赛季（1926- 1928年）。在他的三年中，斯坦福足球队以26-5-3的比分进行了两次前往玫瑰碗的旅行。 1927年，他从比夫·霍夫曼（Biff Hoffman）获得了74码的达阵传球，这是斯坦福大学历史上最长的。

在坦普尔（Temple）执教时，华纳（Warner）继续居住在帕洛阿尔托（Stanford）所在的帕洛阿尔托（Palo Alto）。 1938年退休后，他立即被招募为Dudley Degroot的顾问，Dudley Degroot是斯坦福大学的中心，也是圣何塞州立大学（帕洛阿尔托附近）的主教练。华纳正式成为顾问，立即被任命为犯罪。根据鲍尔斯的说法，“德鲁特一直在使用一次后卫，但流行音乐立即变成了双翼，这对圣何塞球员的怀疑很大。但是，组开始点击了，圣何塞不仅享受了不败的赛季，而且是全美得分最高的球队。”那一年，圣何塞州立斯巴达人与阿莫斯·阿隆佐·斯塔格（Amos Alonzo Stagg）指导的太平洋学院对阵太平洋大学。这是两名教练自1907年以来第一次见面，当时华纳（Warner）执教卡莱尔（Carlisle）并以18-4击败了斯塔格（Stagg）的芝加哥大学。华纳和德格鲁特的圣何塞州立大学以39-0击败了斯塔格的太平洋老虎队。

在有组织的大学大学曲棍球的头40年中，交替被称为ICLA，ILA，USICLL，USILL和USILA，两所宾夕法尼亚州学校，Lehigh和Swarthmore扮演了主导团队。两支球队被评为大学曲棍球的全国冠军，共14（14）个赛季。格伦·“流行”华纳（Glenn“ Pop” Warner）是1899年至1903年卡莱尔印度学校（PA）的名人堂足球教练，在春季他说：“曲棍球是健康和力量的开发者。这是一场旁观者一旦理解了它。”接触运动的曲棍球也很可能有助于为秋季的足球运动员做好准备。到1920年，USILL已扩展到包括锡拉丘兹，罗格斯，宾夕法尼亚州立大学的球队，并受到流行华纳的鼓励，甚至考虑在匹兹堡大学增加了一支大学生队伍。 1920年，大学曲棍球重新调整了协会，增加了南部部门，其中包括来自里海，宾夕法尼亚州和斯沃斯莫尔的强大球队以及传统的马里兰州力量约翰·霍普金斯。该组织今天仍然存在的美国大学间曲棍球协会（USILA）正式成立于1925年11月。
著名的足球教练Glenn Scobey“ Pop” Warner是1939年和1940年斯巴达人的顾问教练，在两个赛季中帮助球队取得了24-1的战绩。

以下是会议的年度最佳球员奖获得者。 2004年，年度最佳防守球员奖更名为Pat Tillman年度最佳防守球员。
帕洛俱乐部每年授予格伦“流行”华纳纪念奖杯，授予西海岸最有价值的高级球员。它是从1950年到2004年授予的。值得注意的是，所有接收者都为Pac-10机构效力。该奖项与无隶属的W. J. Voit纪念奖杯有区别于1951年至1978年，每年向太平洋海岸的顶级球员颁发，无论上课年份。

尽管1915赛季取得了成功，但第二年的球队是华纳职业生涯中最伟大的球队之一。黑豹队再次不败，就像上一年一样，八场比赛中有六场被淘汰。他们的35名球员中有32名来自匹兹堡附近的宾夕法尼亚州西部。球队得分255分，命中25分。华纳认为该队有所改善，因为其防守比上一年更为主导。黑豹队是共识的国家冠军，华纳被公认为足球最伟大的教练之一。
1917年，美国进入了第一次世界大战，一些球员（包括安迪·黑斯廷斯和吉米·德哈特）参加了兵役。尽管战争并未获得全国冠军，但匹兹堡尽管战争没有赢得整整赛季。尽管球队缺乏上一年的拳，但它占据了反对派。其成功的一个关键方面是反对教练无法解决华纳不断发展的策略。根据鲍尔斯的说法，“他的反向戏剧是一个谜，尽管流行音乐总是愿意向任何其他教练详细解释它们”。
report_src: 格伦·斯科比·“流行”华纳出生于1871年4月5日，逝世于1954年9月7日，享年83岁（约83年5个月）[1]。

question_en: What is a Cricket bat called?
pos_context_en: The "blade" of a cricket bat is a wooden block that is generally flat on the striking face and with a ridge on the reverse (back) which concentrates wood in the middle where the ball is generally hit. The bat is traditionally made from willow wood, specifically from a variety of white willow called cricket bat willow ("Salix alba" var. "caerulea"), treated with raw (unboiled) linseed oil, which has a protective function. This variety of willow is used as it is very tough and shock-resistant, not being significantly dented nor splintering on the impact of a cricket ball at high speed, while also being light in weight. The face of the bat is often covered with a protective film by the user.
neg_context_en:
"Law 5: The bat". The bat is no more than in length, no more than wide, no more than deep at its middle and no deeper than at the edge. The hand or glove holding the bat is considered part of the bat. Ever since the ComBat incident, a highly publicised marketing attempt by Dennis Lillee, who brought out an aluminium bat during an international game, the Laws have provided that the blade of the bat must be made of wood.
"Law 6: The pitch". The pitch is a rectangular area of the ground long and wide. The Ground Authority selects and prepares the pitch, but once the game has started, the umpires control what happens to the pitch. The umpires are also the arbiters of whether the pitch is fit for play, and if they deem it unfit, with the consent of both captains can change the pitch. Professional cricket is almost always played on a grass surface. However, in the event a non-turf pitch is used, the artificial surface must have a minimum length of and a minimum width of .

A cricket bat is a specialised piece of equipment used by batsmen in the sport of cricket to hit the ball, typically consisting of a cane handle attached to a flat-fronted willow-wood blade. The length of the bat may be no more than 38 inches (965 mm) and the width no more than 4.25 inches (108 mm). Its use is first mentioned in 1624. Since 1979, a rule change stipulated that bats can only be made from wood.

Batting is the act or skill of hitting the cricket ball with a cricket bat to score runs or prevent the loss of one's wicket. Any player who is currently batting is denoted as a batsman, regardless of their particular area of expertise. Batsmen have to adapt to various conditions when playing on different cricket pitches, especially in different countries: therefore, as well as having outstanding physical batting skills, top-level batsmen will have lightning reflexes, excellent decision-making and be good strategists.

Cricket clothing and equipment is regulated by the laws of cricket. Cricket clothing, known as cricket whites, or flannels, is slightly loose fitting so as not to restrict players' movements. Use of protective equipment, such as helmets, gloves and pads, is also regulated.Batsmen are allowed to wear gloves while batting. The batsman can be also caught out if the ball touches the glove instead of the bat, provided the hand is in contact with the bat. This is because the glove is considered to be the extension of the bat. The batsman may also wear protective helmets usually with a visor to protect themselves. Helmets are usually employed when facing fast bowlers. While playing spinners, it might not be employed.

Any player, regardless of their area of special skill, is referred to as a batsman while they are actually batting. However, a player who is in the team principally because of their batting skill is referred to as a specialist batsman, or simply "batsman", regardless of whether they are currently batting. (A specialist bowler, on the other hand, would be referred to as a "batsman" only while actually engaged in batting.) In women's cricket, the term "bats woman" is sometimes encountered, as is "batter", but 'batsman' is widely used in both men's and women's cricket.

Stoolball is a sport that dates back to at least the 15th century, originating in Sussex, southern England. It may be an ancestor of cricket (a game it resembles), baseball, and rounders, in fact stoolball is sometimes called "cricket in the air". There is a tradition that it was played by milkmaids who used their milking stools as a "wicket" and the bittle, or milk bowl as a bat. Hence its archaic name of "bittle-battle."

"We designed the building from the inside out, not the outside in,” said Loretta H. Cockrum, Foram’s founder, chairman and CEO. “We wanted the most efficient office building ever designed, with no wasted space or wasted energy. This is a building of the future more than a building of the present. A lot of love has gone into that building, and a lot of pride."

Bats are very well equipped to prey upon crickets. While some bats rely purely on mid-flight echolocation to locate their prey, other species locate their prey through passive listening, orienting towards sounds made by the prey, and often emitting a fainter echolocation call as they approach their target. "Teleogryllus oceanicus" crickets have been shown to be able to distinguish a range of echolocation frequencies, responding with avoidance flight away from the bats. Multiple species of bats ("Nyctophilus major" and "N. geoffroyi") have been shown to prefer trills in the cricket song compared to chirps. As a result, male crickets prefer to call from shelter, and the calls from males in shelter contain a greater number of trills than those emitted by a non-sheltered male.

Winfield Toll Bridge, also known as the Ross Booth Memorial Bridge, is a historic three-span cantilever Warren Truss bridge located at Winfield and Red House, Putnam County, West Virginia. It was built in 1955, and spans the Kanawha River, carrying West Virginia Route 34. The cantilever through-truss consists of two anchor spans each 245 feet in length and the main span 462 feet in length between pier center lines. The main span consists of two 128 feet, 4 inch, cantilever arms and a 205 feet, 4 inch, suspended span.
question_src: 什么是板球蝙蝠？
pos_context_src: 板球蝙蝠的“刀片”是一个木制块，通常在醒目的脸上平坦，背面有一个山脊（后部），将木头集中在中间，球通常被击中。蝙蝠传统上是由柳树制成的，特别是由各种称为板球蝙蝠柳树（“ salix alba” var。“ caerulea”）的白色柳树，并用原始（未煮的）亚麻籽油处理，该油具有保护功能。这种柳树被使用，因为它非常坚韧和抗震动，不会显着凹陷或在高速板球球的撞击上分裂，同时也很轻。蝙蝠的脸通常被用户的保护膜覆盖。
neg_context_src:
“法律5：蝙蝠”。蝙蝠的长度不超过宽度，不超过其中间的深处，并且不超过边缘。握着蝙蝠的手或手套被认为是蝙蝠的一部分。自战斗事件以来，丹尼斯·利利（Dennis Lillee）在国际比赛中提出了铝制蝙蝠的高度宣传的营销尝试，法律规定，蝙蝠的叶片必须由木材制成。
“法律6：音调”。音高是地面长而宽的矩形区域。地面管理局选择并准备球场，但是一旦比赛开始，裁判员就会控制球场发生的事情。裁判也是仲裁员是否适合比赛，如果他们认为不适合比赛，则在两位队长的同意下都可以改变球场。专业板球几乎总是在草地上打。但是，如果使用非涡轮螺距，则人造表面必须具有最小长度和最小宽度。
板球蝙蝠是板球运动中板球运动中使用的专门设备，用于击球，通常由拐杖固定在扁平的柳树叶片上的甘蔗手柄组成。蝙蝠的长度可能不超过38英寸（965毫米），宽度不超过4.25英寸（108毫米）。它的使用首先在1624年提及。自1979年以来，规则变更规定只能用木材制成蝙蝠。
击球是用板球蝙蝠击中板球的行为或技巧，以得分跑或防止损失一个人的门。任何目前击球的球员都表示为击球手，无论其特定专业领域如何。板球运动员在不同的板球球场比赛时，尤其是在不同国家 /地区时必须适应各种条件：因此，具有出色的身体击球技巧，顶级板球员将具有闪电反射，出色的决策和成为优秀的战略家。
板球和设备受板球定律调节。板球服装（称为板球白色或法兰绒）略微松动，以免限制玩家的动作。还可以调节使用防护设备，例如头盔，手套和垫子。击打时允许Batsmen戴上手套。如果球与蝙蝠接触，击球手也可以被抓住。这是因为手套被认为是蝙蝠的延伸。击球手通常还可以戴防护头盔，以保护自己。面对快速投球手时，头盔通常会使用。在玩旋转器时，可能不会使用它。
任何球员，无论他们的特殊技能领域如何，都被称为击球手，而实际上是击球手。但是，主要是因为他们的击球技巧的球员主要是专家击球手，或者只是“击球手”，而不管他们目前是击球。 （另一方面，专业的投球手只有在实际从事击球的同时被称为“击球手”。）在女子板球中，有时会遇到“蝙蝠女性”一词，而“击球手”也是如此，但“蝙蝠侠”在男性和女子板球中都广泛使用。
Stoolball是一项至少可以追溯到15世纪的运动，起源于英格兰南部的苏塞克斯。它可能是板球（类似于棒球），棒球和圆球的祖先，实际上，跑步球有时被称为“空中板球”。有一种传统是，它是由挤奶凳作为“检票口”和bittle或牛奶碗用作蝙蝠的挤奶女仆演奏的。因此，其古老的名字是“ Bittle-Battle”。
“我们从内而外设计的建筑物，而不是外部设计。” “我们想要有史以来最有效的办公楼，没有浪费的空间或浪费的能量。这是未来的建筑，而不是当前的建筑物。这座建筑物已经有很多爱，而且很自豪。”

蝙蝠装备精良，可以捕食板球。虽然有些蝙蝠纯粹依靠飞行中的回声定位来定位猎物，但其他物种通过被动聆听来定位猎物，朝着猎物发出的声音定位，并且经常在接近目标时发出一个愚蠢的回声呼叫。 “ Teleogryllus Oceanicus”板球已被证明能够区分一系列回声频率，并随着避免飞行而响应远离蝙蝠的响应。与鸣叫相比，已证明多种蝙蝠（“ Nyctophilus Major”和“ Geoffroyi”）在板球歌曲中更喜欢颤音。结果，雄性板球更喜欢从庇护所打来电话，而居住在庇护所中的呼叫比非固执的男性发出的颤音数量更多。

温菲尔德收费桥（Winfield Toll Bridge），也被称为罗斯·布斯纪念桥（Ross Booth Memorial Bridge），是位于西弗吉尼亚州普特南县温菲尔德（Winfield）和红屋（Red House）的历史悠久的三跨悬臂沃伦·特鲁斯桥（Warren Truss Bridge）。它建于1955年，跨越了卡纳瓦河（Kanawha River），载有西弗吉尼亚州34号公路。悬臂穿越漫游器由两个锚固跨度分别为245英尺，主跨度为462英尺，长度为462英尺。主跨度由两个128英尺，4英寸，悬臂臂和205英尺4英寸的悬架组成。
report_src: 板球蝙蝠是一种击打板球球的工具，其“刀片”由一块木头制成，正面平坦以便于击球，背面呈山脊状以将木材集中在中部产生更大力量[1]；传统材料为白柳树的一个变种——板球蝙蝠柳树（Salix alba var. caerulea），因其坚韧、抗震、不易在高速撞击下凹陷或开裂且重量较轻而被选用[1]；出厂时通常涂覆原始（未煮）亚麻籽油，以增强木材的防护性能[1]；使用者还会在蝙蝠正面贴保护膜以延长使用寿命[1]。

question_en: What Houses comprise the Northern Kingdom?
pos_context_en: According to the Hebrew Bible, the Kingdom of Israel () was one of two successor states to the former United Kingdom of Israel and Judah. Historians often refer to the Kingdom of Israel as the "Northern Kingdom" or as the "Kingdom of Samaria" to differentiate it from the Southern Kingdom of Judah.
neg_context_en: The Northern Isles (; ; ) are a pair of archipelagos off the north coast of mainland Scotland, comprising Orkney and Shetland. The climate is cool and temperate and much influenced by the surrounding seas. There are a total of 26 inhabited islands with landscapes of the fertile agricultural islands of Orkney contrasting with the more rugged Shetland islands to the north, where the economy is more dependent on fishing and the oil wealth of the surrounding seas. Both have a developing renewable energy industry. They also share a common Pictish and Norse history. Both island groups were absorbed into the Kingdom of Scotland in the 15th century and remained part of the country following the formation of the Kingdom of Great Britain in 1707, and later the United Kingdom after 1801. The islands played a significant naval role during the world wars of the 20th century.

"We designed the building from the inside out, not the outside in,” said Loretta H. Cockrum, Foram’s founder, chairman and CEO. “We wanted the most efficient office building ever designed, with no wasted space or wasted energy. This is a building of the future more than a building of the present. A lot of love has gone into that building, and a lot of pride."

Winfield Toll Bridge, also known as the Ross Booth Memorial Bridge, is a historic three-span cantilever Warren Truss bridge located at Winfield and Red House, Putnam County, West Virginia. It was built in 1955, and spans the Kanawha River, carrying West Virginia Route 34. The cantilever through-truss consists of two anchor spans each 245 feet in length and the main span 462 feet in length between pier center lines. The main span consists of two 128 feet, 4 inch, cantilever arms and a 205 feet, 4 inch, suspended span.

The kingdom of the East Angles bordered the North Sea to the north and the east, with the River Stour historically dividing it from the East Saxons to the south. The North Sea provided a "thriving maritime link to Scandinavia and the northern reaches of Germany", according to the historian Richard Hoggett. The kingdom's western boundary varied from the rivers Ouse, Lark and Kennett to further westwards, as far as the Cam in what is now Cambridgeshire. At its greatest extent, the kingdom comprised the modern-day counties of Norfolk, Suffolk and parts of eastern Cambridgeshire.

According to the Hebrew Bible Jeroboam built two places of worship, one at Bethel and one at far northern Dan, as alternatives to the Temple in Jerusalem.() He did not want the people of his kingdom to have religious ties to Jerusalem, the capital city of the rival Kingdom of Judah. He erected golden bulls at the entrance to the Temples to represent the national god. The Hebrew Bible, written from the perspective of scribes in Jerusalem, referred to these acts as the way of Jeroboam or the errors of Jeroboam. ()
question_src: 哪些房屋包括北部王国？
pos_context_src: 根据希伯来圣经的说法，以色列王国是前英国以色列和犹大的两个继任国家之一。历史学家经常将以色列王国称为“北部王国”或“撒玛利亚王国”，以将其与南部犹大王国区分开。
neg_context_src: 北部岛（;;）是苏格兰大陆北海岸的一对群岛，包括奥克尼和设得兰群岛。气候凉爽，温和，受周围海洋的影响很大。总共有26个居住的岛屿，奥克尼的农业岛屿的景观与北部更坚固的设得兰群岛形成鲜明对比，在那里，经济更依赖于捕鱼和周围海洋的石油财富。两者都有发展的可再生能源行业。他们也有一个共同的Pictish和北欧历史。在15世纪，这两个岛屿群体都被吸收到苏格兰王国，并在1707年大不列颠王国成立后仍然是该国的一部分，后来在1801年后的英国。这些岛屿在20世纪的第二次世界大战期间发挥了重要作用。

温菲尔德收费桥（Winfield Toll Bridge），也被称为罗斯·布斯纪念桥（Ross Booth Memorial Bridge），是位于西弗吉尼亚州普特南县温菲尔德（Winfield）和红屋（Red House）的历史悠久的三跨悬臂沃伦·特鲁斯桥（Warren Truss Bridge）。它建于1955年，跨越了卡纳瓦河（Kanawha River），载有西弗吉尼亚州34号公路。悬臂穿越漫游器由两个锚固跨度分别为245英尺，主跨度为462英尺，长度为462英尺。主跨度由两个128英尺，4英寸，悬臂臂和205英尺4英寸的悬架组成。
东角王国与北海接壤，北海和东部的北海与斯托尔河从历史上将其从东撒克逊人划分为南部。据历史学家理查德·霍格特（Richard Hoggett）称，北海提供了“与斯堪的纳维亚半岛和德国北部到达的蓬勃发展”。王国的西部边界从河流，洛克和肯尼特河到更向西，直到现在是剑桥郡的凸轮。在最大的程度上，王国包括诺福克郡，萨福克和剑桥郡东部部分的现代县。

根据希伯来圣经的说法，耶罗波安建造了两个礼拜场所，一个在伯特利，一个在北丹北部建造了俄勒冈州寺庙的替代品。他在寺庙的入口处竖起了金公牛，以代表民族神。希伯来语圣经是从耶路撒冷文书的角度写的，将这些行为称为耶鲁巴姆的方式或耶罗波安的错误。 （）

question_en: Is Alex Fletcher married?
pos_context_en: Fletcher is married to the actor Neil Davies (who appeared in "Brookside" as Robbie Moffatt, an on-screen boyfriend in 2000 and 2001) and with whom she has a daughter, Yasmin, born in 2005 and a son, Hanson, born in 2016. She also has a brother called Bradley. She lives with her husband, son and daughter in Merseyside.
neg_context_en: Alexandra "Alex" Fletcher (born 8 July 1976 in Childwall, Liverpool) is a British actress known for her roles as Jacqui Dixon in "Brookside" and Diane O'Connor in "Hollyoaks".
Alex Fletcher (born 30 April 1999) is an English professional footballer who plays for Plymouth Argyle.
Day announced on 14 February 2014 that he had been dating fellow YouTuber Carrie Hope Fletcher since October 2013. However, Fletcher announced their break-up via Twitter on 14 March 2014.

The story starts with William Fletcher, a young man who is in love with his cousin, Alice. Her father has forbidden her marriage to Fletcher on account of religious difference. After he thwarts Alice's attempt to run away with Fletcher to North America, Alice's father forces her to marry Charles Leslie instead. In despair, Fletcher decides to leave England and relocate to the Massachusetts Bay Colony. In the Bay colony, Fletcher marries an orphan girl named Martha although he is still in love with Alice. He founds a household several miles out of town, and has children; Everell, and two others. He receives word that Charles and Alice Leslie have both died, and that their children, who will be renamed Faith and Hope, will be coming to live with the Fletchers.

On November 4, 1855, Fletcher married Keziah Price Lister from Hallowell, Maine, who had come to Indianapolis in 1851 to become a public school teacher. Lister, whose first husband had deserted her and moved to Texas, obtained a divorce and then married Fletcher. In 1855 Fletcher moved his children and second wife into the Alfred Harrison home on North Pennsylvania Street in Indianapolis, leaving the Wood Lawn house to his son, Miles, and his family.
Fletcher began his law practice in Urbana, Ohio, and was the first attorney practicing law in Indianapolis. He was a prosecuting attorney for the Marion County Circuit Court in 1822 and 1823 and a prosecuting attorney for the Fifth Circuit Court in 1825 and 1826. Fletcher went on to join a law firm with Ovid Butler, Simon Yandes, and Horatio C. Newcomb. On December 26, 1846, Fletcher and Butler dissolved their law practice and collection business, but Fletcher continued to devote time to his farming operations and banking interests.

Fletcher lived in England for a large portion of his life. While in Europe he associated with Amy Lowell, Ezra Pound, and other Imagist poets; he was one of the six Imagists who adopted the name and stuck to it until their aims were achieved. Fletcher resumed a liaison with Florence Emily "Daisy" Arbuthnot (née Goold) at her house in Kent. She had been married to Malcolm Arbuthnot and Fletcher's adultery with her was the grounds for the divorce. The couple married on July 5, 1916. The marriage produced no children, but Arbuthnot's son and daughter from her previous marriage lived with the couple, who later divorced.

Elias is married to Hugh Fletcher, former CEO of Fletcher Challenge and a former Chancellor of the University of Auckland. In 1994, her brother-in-law, Jim Fletcher, was stabbed to death by an intruder in his Papamoa beach house.
Sir Alexander MacPherson Fletcher (26 August 1929 – 18 September 1989), sometimes known as Alex Fletcher, was a British Conservative Party politician.

Fletcher joined "Brookside" in 1990 and played the role of Jacqui Farnham (née Dixon) until the series ended in 2003. In addition to her role in "Brookside", she has made a number of other television appearances, both in acting and presenting roles. These include parts in "Doctors" and "", and a guest presenting role on the chat show "Loose Women". She was also an occasional presenter of the children's series "Why Don't You?"

亚历克斯·弗莱彻（Alex Fletcher）（1999年4月30日出生）是一位英国职业足球运动员，为普利茅斯·阿盖尔（Plymouth Argyle）效力。
Day于2014年2月14日宣布，他自2013年10月以来一直与Youtuber Carrie Hope Fletcher约会。但是，Fletcher于2014年3月14日通过Twitter宣布了他们的分手。

这个故事始于威廉·弗莱彻（William Fletcher），他是一个爱上了堂兄爱丽丝（Alice）的年轻人。由于宗教差异，她的父亲禁止她的婚姻给弗莱彻。在挫败爱丽丝（Alice）逃离弗莱彻（Fletcher）到北美的企图之后，爱丽丝（Alice）的父亲迫使她嫁给查尔斯·莱斯利（Charles Leslie）。绝望，弗莱彻（Fletcher）决定离开英格兰，搬到马萨诸塞州湾殖民地。在海湾殖民地，弗莱彻（Fletcher）嫁给了一个名叫玛莎（Martha）的孤儿女孩，尽管他仍然爱上了爱丽丝（Alice）。他在远离城镇的几英里处找到了一个家庭，并有孩子。埃雷尔（Everell）和另外两个。他听到查尔斯和爱丽丝·莱斯利都死了，他们的孩子将被更名为信仰和希望，将与弗莱彻（Fletchers）生活在一起。

1855年11月4日，弗莱彻（Fletcher）与缅因州哈洛韦尔（Hallowell）的Keziah Price Lister结婚，后者于1851年来印第安纳波利斯（Indianapolis）成为公立学校老师。李斯特（Lister）的第一任丈夫抛弃了她并搬到德克萨斯州，他离婚，然后与弗莱彻（Fletcher）结婚。 1855年，弗莱彻（Fletcher）将他的孩子和第二任妻子搬到了印第安纳波利斯北宾夕法尼亚街的阿尔弗雷德·哈里森（Alfred Harrison）的家中，将木制草坪之家留给了他的儿子迈尔斯（Miles）和他的家人。
弗莱彻（Fletcher）在俄亥俄州的乌尔巴纳（Urbana）开始了他的法律实践，并且是印第安纳波利斯（Indianapolis）执业的第一位律师。他于1822年和1823年担任马里恩县巡回法院的检察官，并于1825年和1826年是第五巡回法院的检察官。弗莱彻（Fletcher）继续与Ovid Butler，Simon Yandes和Horatio C. Newcomb一起加入了一家律师事务所。 1846年12月26日，弗莱彻（Fletcher）和巴特勒（Butler）解散了他们的法律实践和收集业务，但弗莱彻（Fletcher）继续花费时间用于他的农业业务和银行利益。

弗莱彻（Fletcher）在英格兰生活了一生。在欧洲，他与艾米·洛厄尔（Amy Lowell），埃兹拉·庞德（Ezra Pound）和其他成像诗人有关。他是六位采用名字并坚持下去的图像师之一，直到实现目标为止。弗莱彻（Fletcher）恢复了与佛罗伦萨·艾米丽（Florence Emily）的“黛西（Daisy” Arbuthnot）（néegoold）在她在肯特的家中的联络人。她嫁给了马尔科姆·阿布斯诺特（Malcolm Arbuthnot）和弗莱彻（Fletcher）的通奸，这是离婚的理由。这对夫妇于1916年7月5日结婚。婚姻没有生育孩子，但是阿布索诺特（Arbuthnot）的儿子和女儿以前的婚姻与这对夫妇生活在一起，后来离婚。
埃里亚斯（Elias）嫁给了弗莱彻挑战赛前首席执行官，奥克兰大学前总理休·弗莱彻（Hugh Fletcher）结婚。 1994年，她的姐夫吉姆·弗莱彻（Jim Fletcher）在他的帕帕莫阿海滨别墅（Papamoa Beach House）被一名入侵者刺死。
亚历山大·麦克弗森·弗莱彻爵士（Alexander Macpherson Fletcher）（1929年8月26日至1989年9月18日），有时被称为亚历克斯·弗莱彻（Alex Fletcher），是英国保守党政治家。
弗莱彻（Fletcher）于1990年加入了“布鲁克赛德”（Brookside），并扮演了雅克·法纳姆（NéeDixon）的角色，直到系列赛于2003年结束。除了在“布鲁克赛德”中的角色外，她还在表演和扮演角色中扮演了许多其他电视。其中包括“医生”和“”中的零件，以及在聊天表演“ Lose Women”中扮演角色的来宾。她还是儿童系列“你为什么不呢？”的偶尔主持人。
report_src: 是的，亚历克斯·弗莱彻已婚，她的配偶是演员尼尔·戴维斯（Neil Davies）[1]。

question_en: What was the first U.S. aircraft carrier?
pos_context_title_en: Institutions in the Southern Victory Series
pos_context_en: The United States developed the first aircraft carrier, the USS "Remembrance". This ship first sailed in 1920 and assisted the Irish government in suppressing a pro-British rebellion in Ulster. The "Remembrance", for many years, was the only U.S. aircraft carrier. The Pacific War saw the first naval battles where the combatants engaged one another with planes instead of ships. During the Second Great War, several escort carriers were built from converted merchant ship hulls.
neg_context_title_en: List of aircraft carrier classes of the United States Navy
neg_context_en: Whiting sometimes is referred to as the U.S. Navys "father of the aircraft carrier." He had begun agitating for U.S. Navy development of what were then called "plane carriers" in the spring of 1916, and as early as March 1917 he had proposed to United States Secretary of the Navy Josephus Daniels that the Navy acquire a ship with an aircraft catapult and a flight deck, prompting the first serious U.S. Navy consideration of the acquisition of any kind of aviation ship since the American Civil War of 1861–1865. The United States Department of the Navy rejected his proposal on 20 June 1917. In the years between World War I and World War II, however, Whiting would be instrumental in the construction of five of the U.S. Navys first six aircraft carriers and serve as executive officer of its first two. He also served as acting commanding officer of its first carrier at a time when the United States was experimenting with many aspects of the operation of aircraft carriers and their aircraft.

One of the first major operations in which the ships were involved was Operation Eagle Claw launched by "Nimitz" in 1980 after she had deployed to the Indian Ocean in response to the taking of hostages in the U.S. embassy in Tehran. Although initially part of the U.S. Atlantic Fleet, "Dwight D. Eisenhower" relieved "Nimitz" in this operation after her service in the Mediterranean Sea. "Nimitz" conducted a Freedom of Navigation exercise alongside the aircraft carrier in August 1981 in the Gulf of Sidra, near Libya. During this exercise, two of the ship's F-14 Tomcats shot down two Libyan aircraft in what became known as the Gulf of Sidra incident. In 1987, "Carl Vinson" participated in the first U.S. carrier deployment in the Bering Sea, and "Nimitz" provided security during the 1988 Olympic Games in Seoul.

On 1 April 1931, Rear Admiral Joseph M. Reeves took command of Carrier Division 2 (CarDiv 2), becoming the first carrier division commander in the U.S. Navy. Reeves was also designated as Commander Aircraft U.S. Fleet. Carrier Division 2 initially consisted of the U.S. Navy's first true fast aircraft carriers, and , as well as former minesweeper which acted as an aircraft tender and guardship for the two carriers. Under Reeves' leadership, both carriers had previously distinguished themselves in two major naval exercises, the 1929 Fleet Problem IX and the 1930 Fleet Problem X, demonstrating the potential of aircraft carriers and their embarked air groups in naval offensive operations. Aircraft carriers from Carrier Division 2 became the first to embark U.S. Marine Corps aviation units when, on 2 November 1931, squadron VS-14M joined the "Saratoga" and squadron VS-15M joined the "Lexington".

Carrier Strike Group 1 traces its lineage to Carrier Division 1 (CarDiv 1), the U.S. Navy's first seagoing naval aviation formation. It was first organized in October 1930 as part of the Aircraft Scouting Force, U.S. Fleet in the Atlantic. It initially included the U.S. Navy's first aircraft carrier, the , as well as the aircraft tender and the minesweepers and . In 1933, was reassigned to Carrier Division One under Commander Aircraft, Scouting Force, which also included aircraft tender "Wright"; the minesweepers , "Teal", and ; and the rigid airships and . Carrier Division One was initially headquartered at the Coco Solo Naval Air Station located on the Atlantic side of the Panama Canal Zone near Colón, Panama. In 1939, Carrier Division One was transferred to the Pacific Scouting Force. Division aircraft carriers saw service in World War II, the Korean War, and the Vietnam War.

Whiting reported aboard "Langley" on 20 March 1922, the day of her commissioning, as her first executive officer, also serving on an acting basis as her first commanding officer and thus becoming the first person to command a U.S. Navy aircraft carrier. "Langley" was far too slow to keep up with the battle fleet, and her main purpose was to serve as a laboratory for the exploration of the new naval warfare discipline of aircraft carrier operations, with her personnel and those of her embarked air squadrons experimenting to discover what practices worked best. Flying a Vought VE-7, Lieutenant Virgil C. Griffin made the first takeoff from an American carrier from "Langley" on 17 October 1922, and Lieutenant Commander Godfrey Chevalier made the first landing on 26 October 1922 in an Aeromarine 39B. On 18 November 1922, Whiting himself made the worlds first catapult launch of an aircraft from an aircraft carrier while aboard "Langley", piloting a Naval Aircraft Factory PT while "Langley" was at anchor in Virginias York River.

In 1940, Admiral William Halsey recommended construction of naval auxiliaries for pilot training. In early 1941 the British asked the US to build on their behalf six carriers of an improved "Audacity" design but the US had already begun their own escort carrier. On 1 February 1941, the United States Chief of Naval Operations gave priority to construction of naval auxiliaries for aircraft transport. U.S. ships built to meet these needs were initially referred to as auxiliary aircraft escort vessels (AVG) in February 1942 and then auxiliary aircraft carrier (ACV) on 5 August 1942. The first U.S. example of the type was . Operation Torch and North Atlantic anti-submarine warfare proved these ships capable aircraft carriers for ship formations moving at the speed of trade or amphibious invasion convoys. U.S. classification revision to escort aircraft carrier (CVE) on 15 July 1943 reflected upgraded status from auxiliary to combatant. They were informally known as "Jeep carriers" or "baby flattops". It was quickly found that the escort carriers had better performance than light carriers, which tended to pitch badly in moderate to high seas. The "Commencement Bay" class was designed to incorporate the best features of American CVLs on a more stable hull with a less expensive propulsion system.

The Curtiss Carrier Pigeon was an American mail plane of the 1920s. A single-engined biplane designed and built to replace World War I surplus aircraft such as the DH-4, the Carrier Pigeon was one of the first aircraft designed specifically for U.S. Airmail service.
In 1925 the U.S. Postal Service felt they had excellent operational service with converted Airco D.H.4 biplanes. The eight-year-old designs were considered antiquated by this time, however, and a modern purpose-built machine was desired. While most manufacturers started to build new generation passenger aircraft with mail cargo capability, the Curtiss Carrier Pigeon was the first clean-sheet design specifically made for U.S. air-mail service. The aircraft was intended to be sold directly to the Postal Service, but new legislation that opened up outside contracts brought on a slew of competing models.

Over the next two decades Mitscher worked to develop naval aviation, taking assignments serving on the aircraft carriers and , the seaplane tender , and taking command of Patrol Wing 1, in addition to a number of assignments ashore. "Langley" was the navy's first aircraft carrier. A converted collier, she could only make , thus limiting her ability to generate wind over her flight deck and lift under the wings of her aircraft for launching and recovery. Aboard "Langley" Mitscher and other naval aviation pioneers developed many of the methods by which aircraft would be handled aboard U.S. Navy aircraft carriers. Many of these techniques continue to be used in the current-day U.S. Navy.

Following "Ranger" and before the entry of the United States into World War II, four more carriers were commissioned. 
The Imperial Japanese Navy struck Pearl Harbor on 7 December 1941, but none of the Pacific Fleet's aircraft carriers were in the harbor. Because a large fraction of the navy's battleship fleet was put out of commission by the attack, the undamaged aircraft carriers were forced to become the load-bearers of the early part of the war. The first aircraft carrier offensive of the U.S. Navy came on 1 February 1942, when the carriers Enterprise and Yorktown, attacked the Japanese bases in the Marshall and Gilbert Islands. The Battle of the Coral Sea became the first sea battle in history in which neither opposing fleet saw the other. The Battle of Midway started as a Japanese offensive on Midway Atoll met by an outnumbered U.S. carrier force, and resulted in a U.S. victory. The Battle of Midway was the turning point in the Pacific War.
question_src: 美国第一批航空母舰是什么？
pos_context_src: 美国开发了第一批航空母舰“纪念”。这艘船于1920年首次航行，并协助爱尔兰政府压制了阿尔斯特的亲英国叛乱。多年来，“纪念”是唯一的美国航空母舰。太平洋战争看到了第一场海军战斗，战斗人员用飞机而不是船只互相互动。在第二次大战期间，由转换后的商船船体建造了几个护送员。
neg_context_title_src: 美国海军航空公司班级清单
neg_context_src: 惠廷有时被称为美国海军“航空母舰之父”。他已经开始为1916年春季的美国海军发展开发美国海军的发展，早在1917年3月，他就向美国海军部长约瑟夫斯·丹尼尔斯（Josephus Daniels）提议，海军与飞机弹奏甲板和一架飞行甲板一起购买了一艘船，并促使美国海军的第一个认真的美国海军乘船乘坐了18艘国防船舶。美国海军部门于1917年6月20日拒绝了他的提议。在第一次世界大战和第二次世界大战之间的几年中，怀廷将在建设美国海军前六个航空母舰中的五个中有助于建造前两名航空母舰，并担任前两名的执行官。当美国正在尝试航空母舰及其飞机运营的许多方面时，他还担任其第一艘承运人的代理指挥官。

船只参与其中的首批主要业务之一是“尼米兹”（Nimitz）行动的鹰爪行动于1980年发起，因为她为征求美国大使馆在德黑兰的人质而部署到印度洋。尽管最初是美国大西洋舰队的一部分，但“德怀特·艾森豪威尔（Dwight D. Eisenhower）”在她在地中海服役后的这项行动中解除了“尼米兹”的救济。 “尼米兹”于1981年8月在利比亚附近的西德拉海湾与航空母舰一起进行了航行自由活动。在这项练习中，这艘船的两艘F-14 tomcats在被称为西德拉湾事件的两架利比亚飞机中击落了两架利比亚飞机。 1987年，“卡尔·文森（Carl Vinson）”参加了白令海的第一个美国航空公司部署，“尼米兹”（Nimitz）在首尔举行的1988年奥运会期间提供了安全性。

1931年4月1日，海军上将约瑟夫·里夫斯（Joseph M.里夫斯还被指定为美国舰队指挥官。运营商2最初由美国海军的第一个真正的快速航空母舰组成，以及前扫雷机，后者是两家航空公司的飞机招标和守卫。在里夫斯（Reeves）的领导下，两家航空公司以前曾在两次主要的海军演习中出名，1929年的舰队问题IX和1930年的舰队问题X，这表明了航空母舰及其在海军进攻行动中登上空军团体的潜力。来自运营商2的航空母舰成为第一个登上美国海军陆战队航空部队的航空公司，1931年11月2日，中队vs-14m加入了“ Saratoga”和“ Saratoga”，而中队vs-15m加入了“ Lexington”。

运营商罢工组1将其血统追踪到美国海军第一个海上海军航空公司组1（CARDIV 1）。它是1930年10月首次组织的，作为飞机侦察部队的一部分，大西洋的美国舰队。它最初包括美国海军的第一架航空母舰，以及飞机招标和扫雷机和。 1933年，在指挥官驾驶部队的指挥官驾驶部队的一号司令官中被重新分配，其中还包括飞机招标“ Wright”；扫雷器，“蓝绿色”，以及；和僵化的飞艇和。一号运营商最初的总部位于巴拿马科隆附近巴拿马运河地区大西洋一侧的可可独奏海军航空站。 1939年，一号运营商被转移到太平洋侦察部队。师航空公司在第二次世界大战，朝鲜战争和越南战争中看到了服务。

惠廷（Whiting）于1922年3月20日在“兰利（Langley）”上报道说，她作为她的第一任执行官员的委托当天，也是她的第一位指挥官，因此成为第一个指挥美国海军航空母舰的人。 “兰利”太慢了，无法跟上战队的步伐，她的主要目的是作为探索新海军战争纪律的实验室，她的人员和她的人员和她登陆的空中中队的实验以发现哪些做法最有效。 1922年10月17日，驾驶VE-7的VE-7中尉Virgil C. Griffin从“ Langley”中首次从“ Langley”起飞，司令Godfrey Chevalier中尉于1922年10月26日在Aeromarine 39B中首次登陆。 1922年11月18日，惠廷本人从航空母舰上进行了世界首次弹射飞机，而登上“兰利”，驾驶海军飞机工厂PT，而“兰利”在弗吉尼亚州约克河的锚点。

1940年，海军上将威廉·哈尔西（William Halsey）建议建造海军辅助机构进行飞行员培训。 1941年初，英国人要求美国代表他们的六个改进的“大胆”设计，但美国已经开始了自己的护送承运人。 1941年2月1日，美国海军行动负责人优先考虑飞机运输的海军辅助机构。 1942年2月，为满足这些需求的美国船只最初被称为辅助飞机护送船（AVG），然后于1942年8月5日将辅助航空母舰（ACV）称为辅助航空公司。火炬行动和北大西洋反海洋战争证明了这些有能力的船舶航空母舰，用于以贸易速度或两栖入侵车队行驶的船舶。 1943年7月15日，美国对护送航空母舰（CVE）的分类修订反映了从辅助机构到战斗人员的地位。他们被非正式地称为“吉普车”或“婴儿吹牛”。很快发现，护送员的性能要比轻型载体更好，后者往往会在中等到海洋中倾斜。 “开学湾”课程旨在将美国CVL的最佳功能纳入更稳定的船体，并具有便宜的推进系统。

Curtiss载体鸽子是1920年代的美国邮件飞机。载体鸽子是一款旨在替代第一次世界大战盈余的单引擎双翼飞机，它是第一批专门为美国航空邮件服务设计的飞机之一。
1925年，美国邮政局认为，他们与转换后的Airco D.H.4 Biplanes拥有出色的运营服务。到目前为止，这次八岁的设计被认为是过时的，并且需要一台现代的专用机器。尽管大多数制造商开始使用邮件货物能力建造新一代客机，但Curtiss Carrier Pigeon是第一个专门用于美国航空邮件服务的清洁板设计。该飞机旨在直接出售给邮政局，但是开放外部合同的新立法带来了许多竞争模式。

在接下来的二十年中，密西尔（Mitscher）努力发展海军航空，除了上岸的许多任务外，还在航空母舰和水上飞机招标上服役，并指挥巡逻队1。 “兰利”是海军的第一架航空母舰。她只能做一个convert依的煤矿，从而限制了她在飞行甲板上产生风的能力，并在飞机的机翼下抬起，以发射和恢复。船上的“兰利”·米切尔（Langley）和其他海军航空先驱开发了许多方法，通过这些方法将在美国海军航空母舰上处理飞机。这些技术中的许多仍在当今的美国海军中使用。

在“游骑兵”之后，在美国进入第二次世界大战之前，又委托四个承运人。 
日本帝国海军于1941年12月7日袭击了珍珠港，但太平洋舰队的航空母舰都没有在港口。由于这次袭击被委托给了海军战舰舰队的很大一部分，因此未损坏的航空母舰被迫成为战争初期的负载者。 1942年2月1日，美国海军的第一次航空公司攻势是在马歇尔和吉尔伯特群岛的日本基地袭击日本基地的。珊瑚海的战役成为历史上的第一次海战，在那两者之间，舰队都没有看到对方。中途战役开始是日本的进攻，在中途环礁的日本攻势中，美国航空公司人数众多，并取得了美国的胜利。中途之战是太平洋战争的转折点。
report_src: 美国第一批航空母舰被命名为“纪念”（Memorial），它于1920年首次航行，并在服役早期协助爱尔兰政府镇压阿尔斯特的亲英国叛乱；在多年时间里，“纪念”一直是美国唯一的航空母舰[1]。

question_en: Is Georges Sagnac dead?
pos_context_en: Georges Sagnac (14 October 1869 – 26 February 1928) was a French physicist who lent his name to the Sagnac effect, a phenomenon which is at the basis of interferometers and ring laser gyroscopes developed since the 1970s.
neg_context_en: Sagnac was born at Périgueux and entered the École Normale Supérieure in 1889. While a lab assistant at the Sorbonne, he was one of the first in France to study X-rays, following Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen. He belonged to a group of friends and scientists that notably included Pierre and Marie Curie, Paul Langevin, Jean Perrin, and the mathematician Émile Borel. Marie Curie says that she and her husband had traded ideas with Sagnac around the time of the discovery of radioactivity. Sagnac died at Meudon-Bellevue.

The Sagnac effect, also called Sagnac interference, named after French physicist Georges Sagnac, is a phenomenon encountered in interferometry that is elicited by rotation. The Sagnac effect manifests itself in a setup called a ring interferometer. A beam of light is split and the two beams are made to follow the same path but in opposite directions. On return to the point of entry the two light beams are allowed to exit the ring and undergo interference. The relative phases of the two exiting beams, and thus the position of the interference fringes, are shifted according to the angular velocity of the apparatus. In other words, when the interferometer is at rest with respect to the earth, the light travels at a constant speed. However, when the interferometer system is spun, one beam of light will slow with respect to the other beam of light. This arrangement is also called a Sagnac interferometer. Georges Sagnac set up this experiment to prove the existence of the aether that Einstein's theory of special relativity had discarded.

The best known use of the Sagnac interferometer lies in its sensitivity to rotation. The first accounts of the effects of rotation on this form of interferometer were published in 1913 by Georges Sagnac, who mistakenly believed that his ability to detect a "whirling of the ether" disproved relativity theory. The sensitivity of present-day Sagnac interferometers far exceeds that of Sagnac's original arrangement. The sensitivity to rotation is proportional to the area circumscribed by the counter-rotating beams, and fibre optic gyroscopes, present-day descendants of the Sagnac interferometer, use thousands of loops of optical fibre rather than mirrors, such that even small to medium-sized units easily detect the rotation of the Earth. Ring laser gyroscopes (not illustrated) are another form of Sagnac rotation sensor that have important applications in inertial guidance systems.

In 1913, Georges Sagnac showed that if a beam of light is split and sent in two opposite directions around a closed path on a revolving platform with mirrors on its perimeter, and then the beams are recombined, they will exhibit interference effects. From this result Sagnac concluded that light propagates at a speed independent of the speed of the source. The motion of the earth through space had no apparent effect on the speed of the light beam, no matter how the platform was turned. The effect had been observed earlier (by Harress in 1911), but Sagnac was the first to correctly identify the cause.

The Sagnac effect demonstrates that one beam on a rotating platform covers less distance than the other beam, which creates the shift in the interference pattern. Georges Sagnac's original experiment has been shown to suffer extinction effects, but since then, the Sagnac effect has also been shown to occur in vacuum, where extinction plays no role.

It also claimed that white smoke trails such as seen behind the missile on the footage usually occur from land-to-air missile launches, and never with air-to-air missiles.
“This is not a full list of inconsistencies in the obviously edited video footage. [The footage does not give] a clear picture of when and where the video was recorded. If watched carefully, one can clearly see two roads parallel to the shoreline,” the Russian Foreign Ministry said. “But there aren't such roads in the indicated area of Abkhazia’s coast. Abkhazia's famous sand beaches - 100 meters in width - are not seen in the footage, even though they can be seen by satellite.”

The Bridge in Tredyffrin Township was a historic stone arch bridge carrying Gulph Road across Trout Creek in Tredyffrin Township, Chester County, Pennsylvania, USA. It had one span, a solid, semicircular stone arch long. There were stone wing walls at each end, with roughly squared stone voussoirs forming the arch ring. The vault of the arch had been sealed with gunite when the bridge was surveyed in 1982, and the parapets had also been topped with concrete. The bridge was built at an unknown date in the late 19th or early 20th century, and was a well-preserved, typical example of stone arch bridge construction in that period.

question_src: 乔治·萨格纳克（Georges Sagnac）死了吗？
pos_context_src: 乔治·萨格纳克（Georges Sagnac）（1869年10月14日至1928年2月26日）是一位法国物理学家，他的名字借给了sagnac效应，这种现象是自1970年代以来开发的干涉仪和环形激光陀螺仪的基础。
neg_context_src: Sagnac出生于Périgueux，并于1889年进入ÉcoleNormaleSupérieure。当Sorbonne的实验室助理时，他是法国最早在WilhelmConradRöntgen之后研究X射线的人之一。他属于一群朋友和科学家，其中特别包括皮埃尔（Pierre）和玛丽·库里（Marie Curie），保罗·兰格文（Paul Langevin），让·佩林（Jean Perrin）和数学家émileborel。玛丽·库里（Marie Curie）说，在发现放射性时，她和她的丈夫在发现放射性时就与Sagnac交易了想法。 Sagnac死于Meudon-Bellevue。

Sagnac效应，也称为Sagnac干扰，以法国物理学家Georges Sagnac命名，是一种在干涉法中遇到的现象，它是通过旋转引起的。 SAGNAC效应在称为环干涉仪的设置中表现出来。一束光束被拆开，并沿着相同的方向沿着相同的路径行驶。返回进入点后，允许两个光束退出环并受到干扰。两个退出梁的相对阶段以及干扰条纹的位置根据设备的角速度移动。换句话说，当干涉仪相对于地球静止时，光线会以恒定的速度行驶。但是，当干涉仪系统旋转时，相对于另一光束，一束光束会减慢。该布置也称为SAGNAC干涉仪。乔治·萨格纳克（Georges Sagnac）建立了此实验，以证明爱因斯坦（Einstein）特殊相对论的以太存在。

SAGNAC干涉仪的最著名使用在于其对旋转的敏感性。乔治·萨格纳克（Georges Sagnac）在1913年发表了关于旋转对这种干涉仪形式的影响的第一个说明，他错误地认为他检测出了“以太币的旋转”的能力。当今的Sagnac干涉仪的敏感性远远超过了Sagnac的原始布置。对旋转的敏感性与反向旋转梁所限制的面积成正比，光纤陀螺仪（光纤陀螺仪）是SAGNAC干涉仪的当前后代，使用了数千个光纤循环，而不是镜子，即使小到中等大小的单元都可以轻松地检测到地球的旋转。环激光陀螺仪（未说明）是在惯性引导系统中具有重要应用的Sagnac旋转传感器的另一种形式。

1913年，乔治·萨格纳克（Georges Sagnac）表明，如果光束被拆开，并以两个方向发送围绕旋转平台上的封闭路径的两个方向发送，其外围镜子在其周长上，然后将梁重新组合，它们将表现出干扰效果。从这个结果，Sagnac得出的结论是，光在速度独立于源速度的速度下传播。无论平台如何转动，地球通过太空的运动对光束的速度没有明显的影响。效果已经较早地观察到（Harress在1911年），但Sagnac是第一个正确识别原因的人。
SAGNAC效应表明，旋转平台上的一个光束覆盖的距离要比另一个光束少，这会产生干扰模式的变化。乔治·萨格纳克（Georges Sagnac）的原始实验已显示出灭绝效应，但是从那时起，sagnac效应也已显示出在灭绝不起作用的真空中发生。

它还声称，镜头上的导弹后面看到的白烟径通常是从陆地向空中导弹发射出现的，从来没有使用空对空导弹。
俄罗斯外交部说：“这并不是明显编辑的录像中的完整列表。[录像没有给出录像何时何地的清晰图片。 “但是在阿布哈兹海岸的指示区域没有这样的道路。阿布哈兹著名的沙滩 - 宽度100米 - 在录像中没有看到，即使卫星可以看到它们。”

Tredyffrin Township的桥是一座历史悠久的石拱桥，沿着宾夕法尼亚州切斯特县Tredyffrin Township的Trout Creek穿过Gulph Road。它有一个跨度，一个坚固的半圆形石拱。两端都有石翼墙，大致的石头voussoirs形成了拱形戒指。 1982年对桥进行了调查时，拱门的拱顶被密封了，并且护栏还加上了混凝土。这座桥建于19世纪末或20世纪初的一个未知日期，是那个时期的Stone Arch Bridge建筑的一个保存完好的典型例子。
